results.title: ‘I’m the Only Surgeon’: After Haiti Quake, Thousands Seek Scarce Care
results.abstract: A day after a magnitude-7.2 earthquake killed an estimated 1,300 people in western Haiti, the country, already suffering from a dire lack of doctors, struggled to help the many wounded.

multimedia.caption: A wounded woman in Les Cayes, Haiti, being carried to a plane to be airlifted to Port-au-Prince on Sunday.

results.title: Guarding the Last Likeness of a Loathed Dictator? It’s a Thankless Job.
results.abstract: The image of Enver Hoxha, a feared tyrant, was once everywhere in Albania. His last intact statue is watched over by a partly blind, 80-year-old defender. “Nobody wants him anymore.”

multimedia.caption: A bronze statue of Enver Hoxha, Europe’s most enduring and feared communist tyrant, at a stable in the remote mountain village of Labinot Mal, in central Albania.
multimedia.copyright: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

results.title: An Iconic Bridge Sees U.S. Allies Flee Afghanistan as the Soviets Did
results.abstract: Retreating Afghan government soldiers crowded onto a bridge over the Amu Darya River that was a backdrop for the Soviet failure in Afghanistan decades ago.

results.title: Kabul’s Sudden Fall to Taliban Ends U.S. Era in Afghanistan
results.abstract: A takeover of the entire country was all but absolute as the Afghan government collapsed and the U.S. rushed through a frenzied evacuation.
results.byline: By David Zucchino, Jim Huylebroek and Kiana Hayeri
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Taliban fighters in Kabul, the capital, on Sunday on a Humvee seized from Afghan forces. The speed of the Taliban’s sweep through the country startled American officials.

results.title: For Biden, Images of Defeat He Wanted to Avoid
results.abstract: President Biden will go down in history, fairly or unfairly, as the president who presided over a humiliating final act in the American experiment in Afghanistan.

multimedia.caption: After seven months in which the Biden administration seemed to exude much-needed competence, everything about America’s last days in Afghanistan shattered the imagery.

results.title: In Zambia Election, Opposition Leader Storms to Decisive Win Over President
results.abstract: Voters picked Hakainde Hichilema, a businessman who had lost five previous bids for the job, to take over from Edgar Lungu, who has led the southern African nation since 2015.

multimedia.caption: Hakainde Hichilema speaking at his home in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, on Wednesday. His victory was seen as a resounding rebuke of his rival’s shepherding of an economy that was in tatters.
multimedia.copyright: Patrick Meinhardt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Deaths in custody of two brothers fuel anger over Covid enforcement in Kenya.

results.title: In an Overrun Kabul, Many Have No Place to Run
results.abstract: Afghanistan’s capital fell to the Taliban far faster than many had imagined it would, leaving most Afghans with no way out.
results.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Christina Goldbaum, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Ruhullah Khapalwak

results.title: The U.N. chief urges the Security Council to ‘use all tools’ to help Afghanistan.
results.abstract: António Guterres said the organization would not abandon a Taliban-controlled Afghanistan. But he echoed fears, particularly among women, about ‘a return to the darkest days.’

multimedia.caption: People who fled their homes in northern Afghanistan camped out in a park in Kabul last week. The United Nations secretary general expressed alarm about accounts of human rights violations against women and girls.

results.title: Afghans working for U.S. government broadcasters fear Taliban backlash.
results.abstract: The Afghans working for the U.S. government broadcasters in Kabul have long been targets of the insurgents, who killed a journalist  in November.

results.title: A Florida school board defies the governor’s mask ban.
results.abstract: After Broward County officials voted to impose a mandate on face coverings, Gov. Ron DeSantis threatened to revoke their pay.
